comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: Thanks for posting these! The Arthur Syer collection has long been a favourite of mine.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Seconded!  But I had never heard of Arthur K. Syer previously.  I had a quick look through the album, and there are several I picked the locations of immediately.  I hope the series get posted here on Flickr.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Sorry beachcomber! I was sure I'd e-mailed you about this collection last year. Mea Culpa!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] You may well have done; I am going ga-ga!

They are wonderful photos and some look like they are candid shots.  There is a suggestion in the SLNSW blurb that he used a hidden camera.  I wonder how - I thought they were all big cumbersome things on tripods with cloth covers, glass plates, etc.?

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Around the same time as these photos, Paul Martin was taking his candid shots on London's streets and beaches, famously carrying around a camera disguised as a parcel - www.luminous-lint.com/app/image/17450336322251729169181/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Thanks, I had no idea!  Something creepy and stalky about this;  at the same time fascinating ...  I wonder if  Arthur K. Syer had a separate private collection of photos - glimpses of ankle perhaps?!

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: Ha ha! Not that we know of, beachcomber!
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: In Mitchell Pictures we haven't identified this building yet, but it is most likely the first Central railway station, or one of the market buildings in Haymarket. A similar looking building in that area later became part of the Capitol Theatre (but it was not this building).
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] I'm betting on Circular Quay, though I am not sure which jetty (the Manly jetty kept moving). See the large size of this 1893 photo for shape of windows and weatherboard woodwork - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/4289987600/] imho the second (not the first) Sydney Station (1874) doesn't match - www.cityrail.info/about/history/central_station_in-depth ... nor the earlier Belmore Markets (Capitol Theatre) - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3023702508/]

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] B R I L L I A N T !  I like those odds! It's one of those ferry terminal buildings at Circular Quay without a doubt. See also the large size of this c.1899 photo -
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4828624758/]

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw/] Funnily enough my first thought was Haymarket too ...

comment.author: 20958381@N08
comment._content: Nope I had no idea about these either. Awesome fantastic photos!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/statelibraryofnsw] Thanks for the extra information in the blurb at the top.  I am now much wiser.  And a little older.

comment._content:
Found this today:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet/6308748657/]The text talks of May using photographs of the streets of Paris as the basis of his Paris drawings in 1888.
